references:
An alternative to Async-FL is F2LÂ [6],
where clients may have trained for different numbers of iterations when uploading their local models.
Different computing powers of the clients can be efficiently leveraged,
although persistent global aggregation cycles are maintained as in Sync-FL.
However, no consideration has been given to the delays resulting from model uploading under flexible aggregation, which would affect the local training time and performance.
TableÂ I summarizes the existing works and highlights the contribution of this work.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows.
SectionÂ II sets forth the system model.
SectionÂ III formulates the problem of interest.
SectionÂ IV analyzes the convergence bound of the proposed algorithm.
SectionÂ V obtains the optimal assignments of clients, subchannels,
and modulations.
The OFDMA-F2L system is numerically evaluated in SectionÂ VI,
followed by conclusions in SectionÂ VII.
The notations used in this paper is collected in TableÂ II.

A square region that has a side length of 250Â m is considered, with the BS placed at its center, i.e., (0,0,20)0020(0,0,20)Â m.
The sides of the region are aligned with the xğ‘¥x- and yğ‘¦y-axes.
The edge clients are uniformly distributed within the square region, as depicted in Fig.Â 1.
The position of the edge client mğ‘šm is (xm,ym,1.5)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘š1.5(x_{m},y_{m},1.5) m, âˆ€mâˆˆâ„³for-allğ‘šâ„³\forall{m}\in{\cal M}.
We set M=10ğ‘€10M=10 clients. The maximum number of iterations between two sequential aggregations is A=10ğ´10A=10.
We consider Rayleigh fading for both uplink and downlink channels.
The BER requirement of each client is set to Ï‡0=10âˆ’6subscriptğœ’0superscript106\chi_{0}=10^{-6}.
The maximum number of aggregations is G=50ğº50G=50 for the MLP model and G=300ğº300G=300 for the CNN model;
unless otherwise specified.
The model size of the MLP and CNN are 1.018Ã—1051.018superscript1051.018\times 10^{5} and 4.214Ã—1054.214superscript1054.214\times 10^{5}, respectively.
The other parameters are provided in TableÂ III.
